data: An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.

The text is engraved over two lines, on the same field as the relief above, with
                                        a border below.

Wide letters incised in a thin v-cut. Limited use of triangular serifs at the end of
                                    some strokes, and some strokes widen towards the end (e.g. in the letter R). Letters
                                    of late Republican date. Triangular interpuncts between words.

Remains of two lines of monumental letters; the gap below line 2 is greater (up to 7.5 cm) than the gap between lines 1 and 2 (5.5 cm), which could suggest that this is the last line of the text.

Large and very precisely cut letters with neat serifs, with a wide v-cut and a wide module. Interpunct of an elegant comma form (note again that the NSA measurements are incorrect and significantly under).

Eight lines of Greek letters, with the first two lines slightly indented compared to the rest, and a vacat below.

Deeply incised letters, slightly elongated. Alpha is extended at the top, with straight bar; epsilon is in form of a four-bar sigma with middle bar extended to match top and bottom strokes; zeta is regular Z; theta rhomboid with full middle bar; kappa has full length arms; mu has all strokes off vertical, with the middle strokes not fully descending; omicron is rhomboid; pi has overextended crossbar; rho has rounded and closed head; sigma is regular four-bar; omega is rhomboid but open at the base.

Two lines of monumental letters, almost no spacing between the lines, with guidelines visible across the top of line 1.
The letters appear to be cut in a deep wide square cut, with a flat base to the cut; large rhomboid shaped interpunct line 2.
Manganaro argues for c.36 BC in specific context of the civil war; a civil war or Augustan date more generally is plausible.

Four lines of Latin letters, steadily decreasing in height, with lines 1 and 3 set to the left margin, and lines 2 and 4 indented by one letter.

Elegantly carved letters in a fine v-cut, simple serifs, and a broad / square module (O, C, M all very wide), R with an elegant extended tail, P open, M with four full length strokes all off vertical.

Fragment of a dedication to a Roman emperor

The first line is set to the left, with lines 2 and 3 indented by 1.5 letter spaces. The text reduces in size in line 3, and the gap visible below line 3 (up to 32 mm)  is greater than the normal interlineation. Guidelines are visible in lines 2-3, but the letters do not appear to follow them.

Elegant well-spaced quite wide letters with a thin v-cut and pronounced curving serifs on almost all terminations. Letters tend to curvature (e.g. bottom stroke of E, the hook of the G, the tail of the R).P and R are open, G is rounded.  Interpunct not visible in line 1.
116 CE if Manganaro's restoration is accepted, but the potential attributions range through to the following century

The text is engraved in a single line across the middle of the three vertical surfaces on the front face of the stone.

The Technitai of Dionysos honour Skymnos

Neat and regular letters of the later Hellenistic period, in some cases with pronounced serifs. Omicron is full-size; omega is closed; epsilon has shorter middle bar; mu has splayed outer hastae; kappa on occasion has short arms; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; pi has equal vertical strokes and the horizontal overhangs on both sides.

The text appears to observes the shape of the stone, with a fixed left margin and the lines fitting to the line of breakage on the right, and a staurogram centrally filling the space below. The letters retain traces of red paint throughout.

Slightly irregular but neatly carved plain letters without serifs. Alpha has straight bar; Epsilon is rectilinear, with mostly equal length bars; Theta is large and voice, with a full width horizontal bar; Kappa generally has short arms; Lamda has a slight extension at the top; Mu (in ligature) has vertical virst and last, with diagonals extending only half-way down;' rho has small head, closed; sigma is lunate but rectilinear; omega is lunate. Interpuncts are used around numerals.
Photo Museo Arch. Reg. P. Orsi (2012), Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

Text on two lines, with final letter of line 1 squeezed in small before the broken edge of the stone; two birds and christian monograms fill the space below.

Moderately neat and regular letters, cut with a broad groove rather than v-cut, without scerifs, but with extensions to tops of some letters (alpha, delta). alpha has broken bar; epsilon is lunate; kappa has full length arms; omicron is full size; rho has small almost closed eye; sigma is lunate but rectilinear; phi is circular with extended vertical; omega (in symbols below) is lunate.
Carini, 1872, Annotazioni sul sarcofago rinvenuto in Siracusa

The text maintains a regular left margin, ignoring the irregularity of the form of the stone, and filling the space to the right; however, the cutter ran out of space at the end of the stone, and inserted the remaining letters of the word Î”ÎµÎºÎµÎ¼Î²ÏÎ¯á¿³ and the concluding staurogram, firstly at the end of line 2 (letter Î²) and then, under a 'paragraphos' line to the left of the main text of line 2, level with lines 3 (letters ÏÎ¹Ï‰) and 4 (staurogram)

plainly cut, relatively regular letters, in a curved groove rather than v-cut, without serifs. Alpha has an oblique crossbar, sloping down to left, and a horizontal stroke to left off the top of the letter; beta has closed eyes, the upper is smaller; epsilon is lunate (except for the first in line 5 which is rectilinear); zeta has regular Z form; kappa has near full-legnth arms; mu has cursive form; omicron is full size; rho has closed eye; sigma is lunate; omega is lunate.

Seven lines of Greek letters, with traces of red paint. Lines 1-3 are more formally / monumentally carved, from line four onwards the carving is lighter and less carefully laid out, rising to the right.

Simple, thinly incised letters without serfis or terminations. The letters become increasingly ireregular and variable in the final lines. Alpha has striaght bar but also broken and oblique bar; beta has closed roughly equal eyes; Epsilon is quadrate with equal length bars; Zeta is Z in form but irregular; theta is ovoid with full straight bar; kappa has shorter arms; omicron mostly slightly smaller than other letters; sigma is lunate but square in form, lower bar slanting downwards, except for the irregular curved instance end of line 2; omega is in the form of a w, but formed entirely of straight lines and right angles. interlineation is highly irregular throughout.

Six lines of text, of which the first four are neatly and regularly set out between guidelines, but the final two are squeezed into the remaining space, centred but unevenly and without guidelines.

Clear V-cut letters without serifs of somewhat uneven width, consistent height over the first four lines, more irregular thereafter. Alpha with broken bar and stroke rising off the apex; Beta with closed but separated eyes; delta with stroke rising off the apex; epsilon lunate in line 1 but regular in line 2; theta ovoid with full straight cross-bar; kappa has full length arms; mu has vertical first and last, and short middle strokes; omicron varies in size and from round to ovoid; pi is equal length with overlapping horizontal; rho has small closed eye; sigma is lunate, but rectilinear; omega is lunate and small above the line.

Six lines, of which lines 2-6 are indented by one letter compared to line 1, with a consistent left margin. The final line is shorter with the numeral larger and roughly centred. Mommsen suggested that the age formula in lines 5-6 was a later addition, seemingly for its slightly greater irregularity.
Lunate epsilon and sigma, cursive omega, with terminations rather than serifs; use of ligatures. Delta has extended top stroke. Some curvature of longer strokes and arms.

Five lines of Greek text, with a regular left margin, but uneven right margin; line 3 in particular shows signs of cramping in the second half. The lower half of the final line is lost through damage.

Neat, regular letters, mostly of wide module, without serifs. Alpha is broad with straight bar; epsilon has notably short middle bar; kappa has arms of almost full length; omicron is only lightly smaller than other letters (19-20 mm); pi has even length vertical hastae; rho has small closed round head; sigma is four bar with extended horizontal top and bottom strokes; upsilon is neatly symmetrical; phi has small circular eye with vertical only slightly extended (26 mm); omega is full-size and nearly circular, closed, with long horizontal.
later Hellenistic (i.e. 2nd or early 1st century BCE)

Inscription recording the neaniskoi of the gymnasium

The text fills the face available below the cornice (and seems likely to have continued below), with probably a consistent left margin, but a less regular right margin, and some cramping in order to fit words/phrases to the line (as e.g. in line 1).

The letters are mostly regular with a fairly square module and terminal points to the strokes rather than serifs. Alpha has broken cross-bar; epsilon has nearly equal bars; zeta in the form of an I with broad crossbars; kappa has short arms; mu has sloping outer strokes and half-height mid-strokes; omicron is nearly full-size, and consistently has a central dot (in lines 2 and 3 appears to have a line underneath); rho has rounded closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes, and the mid-strokes extend almost the full width; phi is standard height, elliptical; omega is consistently a closed circle (without the central dot of omicron), sometimes on the baseline, sometimes traversed by the line.

Two lines of Greek letters on the side of the chest

Tall regular letters, deeply cut: Alpha with broken bar; omicron in rhomboid form; sigma lunate but square in form; kappa with short arms; epsilon standard with equal length horizontal bars; a large diamond shape interpunct in line 1

1á¼ˆ(Ï…Î»Î¿Ï‚) Â· á¼ŒÎ½Î½Î¹Î¿Ï‚
2ÎšÎ­Î»ÎµÏ
Latin text, aligned to the left margin over two lines, with guidelines (no interlinear spacing)

Somewhat irregularly spaced tall letters, with thin strokes but pronounced terminations to the strokes.  A has a detached downward descending middle-bar; E is tall thin, with shorter top bar; G is formed as a C with the tail a second short curving stroke; P is closed; R has small eye, slightly open; S leans forward slightly. The use of interpuncts is erractic and seemingly not linked to sense, with a triangular punct after the initial A and at the end of line 2; a large reversed comma-shape midline after the R of line 1; and a smaller comma-shape mid-line between V and R in line 2.

Remains of two lines of text, broken off top and bottom, neither complete in height
Neatly carved large v-cut letters, with light serifs. The tail of the R has an extended serif along the line; N is close to square in form. Traces of red paint are visible.
High imperial in date, 1st or earlier 2nd century CE

Fragment of a Latin funerary inscription
Four lines of Latin letters, with an uneven left margin, and of varying heights, the final line much smaller and with space mid-line.

Neat v-cut letters of rather square/blockish style, with simple straight serifs to ends of the strokes. T in line 2 is enlarged (50mm) and as is final I in line 4. Interpuncts of triangular form. C is large and asymmetrical; E has equal length horizontals.
fragment of a latin funerary inscription

1BÌ£uÌ£rÌ£oÌ£[---]
2T(itus) Â· Flav[---]
3Caelia [---]
4sibi Â· (vac.)[---]
Well-spaced lines filling the width of the available stone, word-breaks do not observe line-end.

Somewhat irregular deep-cut letters with pronounced terminations and occasionally extravagant serifs/flourishes (e.g. on X or E), and a varying tendency to the later narrow elongated style (e.g. TFL in line 5), and M sometimes with the upper strokes extended well above the join. A consistently lacks a cross-bar; E generally has equal length strokes, but with the top stroke often extended upwards; F, tall, narrow, and upward pointing; M sometimes with extended apices, sometimes without (all four strokes full length); P is closed; R sometimes open, with extended tail; X frequently over extended upper right. No interpuncts.
mid-2nd century to mid-4th century CE
Photo J. Prag (2015), Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

l.4 reg., orig. ux xor | l.7 reg., orig. vix xit
Text laid out with separating lines on the lower portion of the stone, filling the width, with a blank space above.

Lunate letters of plain form, getting smaller from line 1 to line 4; the fifth line is much larger and Agnello suggests a different hand. Alpha has straight bar throughout; Epsilon is mostly lunate but somewhat variable; zeta in form of straight Z; Kappa has detached arms; Mu in first instance has middle strokes joining very high, in second instance four equal length oblique strokes; xsi is vertical with three equal horizontals; omicron full size; pi straight strokes of equal length; rho rounded and closed; sigma lunate.

Three lines of Latin letters, the first two with a consistent right margin, the third finishing much shorter, and a clear vacat below (up to c.50 mm) suggesting any fourth line significantly shorter. Lines 2 and 3 have guidelines along the upper edge of the line.

Remains of two lines of Greek letters, with a single letter vacat at line beginning and a distinct vacat below the second line.

Described by Orsi as fine, small, regular characters of the fourth or third century BCE; Alpha has straight bar; Epsilon has shorter middle bar; omicron is smaller than other characters and mid-line; sigma is four-bar with top and bottom strokes angled moderately outwards, middle strokes extending almost full-width.
Fourth or third century BCE on the basis of lettering.

Three lines of Greek letters, seemingly not centered / regularly laid out.

Described by Orsi (1896) as 'scritto a pessimi caratteri', and (1899) as 'lettere cattive, rustiche cosi che a tutta prima sembrano archaiche, e molto sconservate... L'iscrizione negligentemente redatta e scolpita Ã¨ funebre di tarda etÃ '. Pace states 'lettere del III sec. av. Cr.', but given the presence of lunate epsilon and Orsi's comments, a later date seems much more likely.
Suggested to be of later Roman date by Orsi on the basis of lettering etc.

1[---]Î˜ÎŸÎÎ™[---]

Text over five lines, carefully following guidelines to the base of each line, with a marginal guideline to the left and right, with the left margin consistently observed. An additional guideline below is unused; the guidelines carefully align with the text to the right of this one. Use of a vacat prior to the age at death.

Deep and wide slightly crude v-cut, producing consistent fairly square letters without serifs. Alpha has mostly downward left sloping cross-bar; epsilon is lunate with mostly shorter middle bar; zeta has slight curvature to the strokes; kappa has short arms; mu has four full-length diagonal strokes; lunate sigma, but note final square lunate for digamma / stigma for numeral 6.

Text over six lines, set in a recessed panel in the style of a temple facade, but without guidelines. Some use of interpuncts and vacats in the text.

Text is deeply incised in letters of slightly varying size. Extensive use of serifs, with several letters tending to the cursive. Alpha has straight bar, curving ends; epsilon is lunate with equal length mid-bar; zeta is large and curved; kappa has near full-length arms; mu has slanting strokes that reach the lower line, but often join before the top and have extended upper strokes; pi has overlapping cross bar; rho has closed eye; sigma is lunate. Elegant hedera in line 2; use of vacats in age at death.

Text over five lines, neatly respecting gridlines to the base of each line and with marginal lines to left and right - that on the left is approximately followed, that on the right is ignored; an additional gridline below is unused. Some use of interpuncts and vacats in the text. The first line shows clear traces of red paint in the letters.

Text is incised in fairly tall, thin, neat and plain letters mostly without serifs. Alpha has downward left sloping cross-bar; epsilon is lunate, with shorter and sometimes detached middle bar; zeta is straight; eta sometimes has detached cross-bar (line 4); kapa has short arms; mu has angled strokes, the mid-strokes only descending half-way, and no upward extension of the apexes; omicron is slightly smaller than other letters; pi does not overlap; rho i slcosed; sigma is lunate. Use of a simple/stylised hedera in lines 2 and 4, and letters are somewhat irregularly spaced especially in the final line.

The left margin of the text is carefully justified, but the right margin is very uneven, with several extensive vacats at line end.

Regular small letters of generally consistent size, deeply cut with pronounced terminal serifs on some strokes. Alpha is broad with straight bar, occasional extension of apex; beta appears open with rounded but not fully circular equal loops; epsilon has shorter middle bar, and upper and lower strokes often curve outwards at the ends; theta is ovoid with complete horizontal bar; kappa has short, equal length tails; mu has middle stroks joining well above the line; nu has the lower right angle above the line with shorter right vertical stroke; omicron is smaller and above the line; pi has shorter right vertical; rho is closed with generally circular eye; sigma has upper and lower horizontals curving slightly outwards at the ends, and the middle strokes often form into a single curving stroke; phi has a rounded eye, with the vertical extended, up to 17mm; psi has extended vertical and straight arms; omega is small, rounded, above the line, and open, with generally horizontal tail strokes.
Manganaro, 1981, L'oracolo di Maie per una carestia in territorio siracusano

Small altar of Zeus Soter Hieron
Two lines of Greek text in the field on the front face of the altar (8.5 cm wide x 2.5 cm high)

The first three letters are more deeply engraved, the remaining letters are little more than scratched in the surface with a sharp point, and are increasingly irregular in form. Omega is open; top and bottom bars of sigma tending slightly apart; omicron is small than other letters; epsilon has horizontals of equal length.

Remains of four lines of Greek text, of which the preserved traces suggest that lines 1-3 filled the width of the stone, but line 4 is more widely spaced and has a vacat at the right, and below.

Regular widely spaced, finely incised letters, of consistent height throughout. Letters have basic triangular terminations to the strokes. Alpha is broken-bar; epsilon has short middle stroke (whether detached or not is unclear); kappa has equal length short arms; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes, with the middle strokes extending half-width.
The letter forms would suggest later third or more likely second century BCE

Four lines of Greek letters; the text appears to be centred on the stone, with slight vacat below.

. Based upon the single published photograph: regularly and neatly carved fine lettters without serfis or significant terminations. Alpha has straight bar; Mu has vertical first and last, with midstrokes descending halfway; omicron is small and mid-line; sigma has diverging top and bottom strokes, the mid-strokes meeting at half width; omega is nearly full height, slightly ovoid, open with short horizontal tails. No editor records the size of the letters.
4th century or 3rd century BCE based on the letters.

Statue of Demeter with inscribed base

The text is engraved over six lines on a flat field 30.3 cm wide and 12-13 cm
                                        high. The left and right sides of this field are cut smooth, the upper and lower
                                        edges are uneven. The lower right and left corners are slightly damaged. The
                                        inscription is intact apart from damage to the middle of line 1 where the upper
                                        front edge of the plinth has been damaged. There is a clear vacat to the bottom
                                        and right of the text. The first line is larger and extends to left and right of
                                        the rest of the text. Lines 2-6 have a consistent left margin.

Alpha has broken bar; epsilon and sigma are lunate; omega is lightly but clearly
                                    rhomboid; omicron is smaller than the other letters and sits above the line; phi is
                                    extended well above and below the line.

The people of Tauromenion honour Nymphodoros son of Eukleides
Three lines of Greek letters, centred on the stone in the upper half of the front face, with some spacing between words.

Letters are fairly deeply incised with terminal points rather than true serifs. The module is slightly irregular, with line 2 smaller than lines 1 and 3. Alpha consistently has broken bar; omicron is full size; mu has vertical first and last, with midstrokes only descending half-way; epsilon consistenly has an overextended top stroke, and a short middlebar; omega is a closed circle on top of the base line; theta is a full circle with short detached crossbar; phi has a small eye with extended vertical; kappa has full length arms.

The dating is somewhat disputed: the individual is commonly identified with the three-time stratagos of the city in  = IG XIV.421, for years 68, 82, and 97. However, the anchoring of the stratagoi list in absolute terms is less certain, even if the start date is generally agreed to fall somewhere in the middle or later third century BCE. If that date is accepted, and assuming the identification of the stratagos with the individual honoured here, then the date should fall somewhere in the first half or middle of the second century BCE. However, Battistoni (2020 p.176) rejects the identification, on the grounds that in his view the palaeography of this inscription is incompatible with such a date (he considers it to be palaeographically more recent than the base for Marcellus of the 70s BCE, IG XIV.435 = ). Palaeographic arguments seem weak in this context (and contrast the discussion of Muscolino 2009-2010, pp. 440-444, who reaches similar conclusions to those presented here) and the identification seems plausible, suggesting therefore a date between, very approximately, 200 and 140 BCE.

The people of Tauromenion honour Nymphodoros son of Philistion
Four lines of Greek letters of equal height, centred on the upper two thirds of the front face of the base.

Deeply incised letters with a regular module (although with a little bit of cramping in lines 2 and 3) and of even height throughout. Terminal serifs of a simple wedge form. Alpha is consistently pronounced broken bar; epsilon has shorter middle bar, only lightly connected, with slight overlap of the top and bottom bar; theta is a full circle, with a short detached mid-stroke; kappa has shorter arms (especially the lower arm); mu has vertical outer strokes, with the middle strokes extending three-quarters of the way down to the base line; omicron is full size; pi has slightly overlapping crossbar, with equal length verticals; rho a large rounded eye; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes, with a slight extension at the join of the mid-strokes; phi has small eye with slightly extended vertical; omega is slightly smaller than the other letters, tear-drop shaped, joined to the base line (but the eye does not close before the baseline)

Perhaps second century BCE from the palaeography, and likely to be approximately associated with the base next to which it was found, ISic003124. The individual is not directly attested in the other Tauromenion texts, but the name Philistion occurs repeatedly, with Philistion son of Philistion holding the position of stratagos in year 94 of IG XIV.421 = ISic001246; since that Philistion is also given the ?demotic Î£Î Î‘Î¡, this could be that man's son, which would suit a date in the middle of the second century or a little later (cf. Muscolino 2009-2010 p.441 with n.117).

The text is set over two lines, neither fully centred, nor fully aligned to the left, on the upper half of the front face of the stone.

Wide square letter forms, simple deep strokes without serifs. Alpha with broken bar; epsilon variously has shorter middle bar (1st and 3rd) or strokes of equal length (2nd); M has vertical first and last strokes, with the middle strokes only descending halfway; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes, with variable middle strokes.
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Museo archeologico regionale Paolo Orsi, 2022-04-29

The Syracusans honour King Gelon, son of Hieron II

Three lines of finely carved Greek letters, centred on the stone (line one with short vacats at beginning and end, line 2 fully filling the face of the stone, line 3 centred with substantial vacats before and after.

Elegant wide and very regular letters with thinly carved strokes. Broken bar alpha; beta with equal sized loops; epsilon with short middle bar; kappa with short arms; mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes to half-height; omicron normally full size but small in line 2 (compression a factor); rho with almost fully rounded eye; sigma with approximately horizontal top and bottom strokes or very slightly open; omega full-size rounded and open with straight feet.

Funerary inscription for Xenokritos son of Hephaistokles, of Massalia

Three lines of Greek text engraved across the full width of the front face. The
                                        third line is slightly smaller than the first two. There is damage to the left
                                        margin of all three lines, and across the lower edge of the third line. The face
                                        is weathered and the letters are faint, especially at the end of the second
                                        line.

Very regularly and elegantly engraved letters without serifs, wide forms, evenly
                                    spaced. Sigma has diverging top and bottom bars; epsilon short middle bar; omicron
                                    perfectly round, smaller then the other letters (c.21 mm) and mid-line; omega is
                                    round, smaller than other letters, and open at the bottom; alpha has straight bar;
                                    kappa has full-length legs; phi has a elliptical eye. The letters are very similar
                                    to those of dated Hieronian inscriptions, i.e. third century BC.
Manganaro, 1992, Massalioti per il Mediterraneo: tra Spagna, Sardegna e Sicilia

Somewhat irregular sized letters, not strictly following the horizontal. Pronounced but simple heavy serifs on deep v-cut letters. The text extends across the full surviving width of the middle band of the front face.

Slightly unevenly spaced deeply v-cut letters. Delta has a slight apex; Mu has vertical first and last, middle strokes only descend half-way; Nu has lower right angle slightly above the line; omicron is full size; rhos has small closed, curved eye; sigma has prallel top and bottom strokes, with relatively shallow mid-strokes; phi has large rhomboid body, traversed by the vertical which is extended (120 mm); omega is open, rounded, with long horizontal tails, and is slightly smaller than the full line-height (75-85 mm).

1[---]Î¤ (vac.1)ÎÏ…Î¼Ï†ÏŒÎ´Ï‰ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î”Î¹ÏŒÎ´Ï‰[ÏÎ¿Ï… ---]
The text is neatly laid out with a clear left margin on a single field below the moulding; divisions in the text at lines 5-6 and 25-26 are marked by paragraphoi.

Letters are regular and deeply cut, with slightly prounced serifs at the end of strokes. Alpha is broad with straight bar, and occasional tendency to apex at the top; beta has equal sized, closed, shallow loops; epsilon has shorter middle bar and slightly outward pointing top and bottom bars; zeta is formed by a vertical with horizontals top and bottom; theta is slightly ovoid in form, with a complete cross bar; kappa has short, equal length tails; Mu has slightly inward leaning first and final strokes, with the middle strokes meeting well above the middle of the line; nu has a shorter right hand stroke, with the lower angle above the line; omicron is small and mid-line; Pi has a slightly shorter right hand vertical; rho has small closed eye, of varying form (rounded or elongated); sigma has slightly outward facing top and bottom storkes and the middle strokes are sometimes rounded at the join; upsilon has shallow spreading upper strokes; phi has a rounded eye, with extended vertical stroke; chi is consistnly slightly larger than other characters; omega open, slightly smaller and above the line, with horizontal tails. A horizontal stroke is visible above and the left of the first letter of lines 6 and 26.
2nd century BCE (principally on the basis of letter forms

Funerary inscription for Nikasis, son of Aristokrates

Two lines of Greek letters in very light relief, centred in a slightly recessed
                                        field in the middle of the front face.

The letters of line 1 are widely spaced. The letters of line 2 are much more tightly
                                    spaced. The letters preserve traces of paint, and appear to have been painted
                                    alternately blue and red. The letters are extremely neatly carved, regular, elegant
                                    and thin, in a light but full relief (on which see below). Letter forms of note
                                    include the kappa (arms are symmetrical and do not extend to the top and bottom of
                                    the line); alpha (very broad and straight); sigma (consistently formed with open
                                    upper and lower bars); omicron (smaller than the other letters and mid-line);
                                    epsilon (shorter middle-bar).
Photo J. Prag: Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

Five lines of Greek text, centred on the stone, with a consistent left margin, and final line (numerals) centred between ivy leaves.

Letters are deeply v-cut, somewhat elongated, and showing some tendency towards curvature in e.g. the M. Minial use of serifs. Lunate omega, but rectilinear epsilon and sigma. Alpha with broken bar; mu with four full-length, slanting strokes; kappa with short ams; omicron ovoid but full height; epsilon tall and thin, all bars of equal length; zeta an equal length Z. Use of interpunct to mark off the names, and hedera around the numeral.
Photo J. Prag, 2014-09-10, by permission of Museo Archeologico Regionale Paolo Orsi

Remains of three lines of text, of which only the middle line is preserved to full height. Text is laid out between double guidelines.

Relatively tall and thin letters, but still of regular square form, of somewhat irregular width, with short basic serifs at the end of strokes; somewhat roughly chiselled. R has an extended tail which does not reach to the lower line; O is tall and narrow; E has slightly shorter middle stroke. M is narrow, with very short middle strokes that join at the midpoint and join  the verticals well below the top.

Five lines of Greek letters, with irregular left margin.

Letters are plainly cut with minimal serifs on stroke terminations. Alph with straight bar and rounded apex; lunate epsilon and sigma; zeta in form of Z; kappa with full-length arms; rho with fairly large rounded and closed eye.

Text is approximately centred on the stone, with a consistent left margin for lines 2-5, lines 1 and 6 centred.

Simply cut letters without notable serifs. Interpuncts are used but not consistently. Alpha has straight bar; epsilon is rectilinear with equal length bars; zeta is a plain Z; theta is rhomboid with detached cross-bar; kappa has slightly shortened arms; omicron is rhomboid; rho has closed round loop; sigma is rectilinear with horizontal bars; omega is rhomboid and open.

Five lines of Greek letters, with line 1 centred, lines 2-5 with a regular left margin.

Simply and neatly cut letters with almost no serifs, well-spaced horizontally, but with minimal interlinear spacing. Simple interpuncts used frequently but inconsistently. Alpha has broken bar; epsilon is rectilinear with equal length bars; zeta is simple Z; theta is rhomboid with detached cross-bar; kappa has slightly shortened arms; omicron is rhomboid; rho has small closed and rounded eye; sigma is rectilinear with horizontal top and bottom strokes.

Four lines of Greek text, somewhat compressed and uneven lines with a consistent left margin.

Cleanly v-cut letters, lunate in form but somewhat irregular in size, without serifs. Alpha has straight bar and slight apex; epsilon is lunate; zeta is plain Z; kappa has full length arms; mu has vertical first and last, with middle strokes only descending halfway; rho has small curved but open loop; sigma is lunate; omega is large and lunate.

Text on one straight line, gap on the right, etched on the fresh plaster. Before the inscription, along the left side, two big letters in column, made of colored glass paste mosaic tiles. Impressions of other tiles between the 2nd and 3rd letter of the inscription, within the 4th and between the 5th and the 6th. Letters and the random mosaic tiles, fixed on the fresh plaster and therefore contemporary to the etched inscription, perhaps represent a rough decoration, also repeating the first two letters of the deceased's name.
